array.string: This is a tip. A tip will show up when you start the app unless you turn it off in the settings menu.
A quick way to switch between training and listening modes is by pinching. Pinch out for listening mode and in for training.
Think you mastered all the intervals? Try switching up the playmode for a new challenge.
If you think things are playing too fast or too slow you can change the tempo in the settings menu.
Changing the root and high octaves in settings will set a range of octaves that notes will play in.
Want to stay in one octave while training? You can set the low and high octaves to both be C3 or C4. This will keep you in one octave.
Want to know how well you are doing? Scroll up to view stats for your current session.
If you are having a hard time guessing the intervals try listening mode. Tap any interval in this mode to hear how it sounds.
Has this app improved your ability to recognize intervals or chords? If so why not give us a good rating or share it with your friends.
If you devote time to practicing daily, you can develop an instant recognition of intervals.
If you are new to intervals we recommend you start on beginner difficulty. As you train you can work your way up to pro.
Try to listen for intervals as they come throughout the day, as you practice you will notice them more and more.
Devote more attention to intervals you are having the most trouble with. Try listening mode to get a better idea of how they sound.
The perfect fifth has a very clear resonance. It is stable and pure. The fifth will sound very clean and pleasant to your ear.
The fifth and the fourth are the closest of all intervals and are often confused. Try to listen for small differences between them.
The resonance of a major third is bright and vibrant, while the minor third is dark and mellow.
The tritone has its own distinct sound and is unique among other intervals.
Chords are made up of combinations of intervals.
The four basic triad chords are made up of a major or minor third and a perfect or augmented fifth.
If you can't recognize a chord when the notes are played together, change the playmode to separate the notes.
Try listening mode if you are having a hard time. Listen to the chords and try to notice each one's particular resonance.
